attributes.title: Impact of Personality on Attitudes towards Diversity and Diversity Initiatives

q1.value: Impact of Personality on Attitudes towards Diversity and Diversity Initiatives

q3.value:
In the recent years, there has been an increased interest in examining attitudes towards diversity and diversity initiatives. Some of this work has started to investigate potential factors that motivate people’s endorsement for diversity initiatives. One such factor is trait personality. Trait personality has been consistently shown to play a role in predicting many important life outcomes, e.g., academic and workplace performance, relationship outcomes, health issues, social attitudes, etc. (e.g., Soto, 2019). Thus, it is reasonable to suggest that trait personality also likely predicts people’s attitudes towards diversity.

Within the literature that examined the relationships between attitudes towards diversity and Big Five personality traits, it has been shown that trait Openness to Experience is the most relevant personality variable in predicting receptiveness to diversity, and its relationship to diversity is motivated by an interest to explore and understand differing perspectives. Another relevant trait is Agreeableness, and it is motivated by an interest to care for and empathize with other individuals. Different studies have found significant positive relationships between Openness and Agreeableness with the universal-diverse orientation (UDO), the mostly frequently used diversity measure in the literature (Han & Pistole, 2017; Strauss & Connerley, 2003). The construct of UDO (Miville, 1999) is generally assessed using the M-GUDS Scale, and has been shown to be positively related to positive racial identity (for both Blacks and Whites), empathy, and feminism, as well as negatively related with dogmatism and homophobia. Zhang and Goldberg (2014) found that Openness was positively correlated with pro-diversity belief and sensitivity to diversity, whereas Agreeableness was only related to pro-diversity belief.

Although studies have explored the general relationships between the Big Five traits (notably Agreeableness and Openness to Experience) and varying diversity measures, fewer studies have extended these findings into more practical, real-life settings, e.g., the workplace. The studies that do discuss practical implications for diversity trainings and initiatives in light of personality differences (Han & Pistole, 2017; Zhang & Goldberg, 2014), still do not focus on specific workplace outcomes or diversity initiatives. On the other hand, research that does specifically address receptivity to diversity in the workplace fails to consider individual personality differences as variables that may impact diversity attitudes. Instead, these studies tend to focus on basic demographic variables, such as race and gender, interpersonal relationships, and organizational culture (Soni, 2000).

The current studies aim to fill in these links within the literature by examining both attitudes towards diversity in general and attitudes towards diversity initiatives in the workplace, while focusing on the potential influences of individual differences. Study 1 explored the relationships between Big Five personality and attitudes that employees have toward diversity in the workplace. Study 2 aimed to in part replicate the findings of Study 1, as well as extend Study 1 by investigating how personality and general attitudes towards diversity related to potential diversity initiatives proposed by the individual’s employer, to capture both past and potential future support. We also examined whether personality and attitudes towards diversity would predict participants’ willingness to donate to other diversity-supporting institutions (Studies 1 and 2).

q4.value:
Study 1 Hypotheses:
H1a: Openness to Experience will positively predict all three diversity measures (universal-diverse orientation, pro-diversity belief, and sensitivity-to-diversity), as well as willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H1b: Agreeableness will positively predict two of the diversity measures, (universal-diverse orientation and pro-diversity belief), as well as willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H1c: The three diversity measures will mediate the links between personality traits (Openness to Experience and Agreeableness) and willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions.

Study 2 Hypotheses:
H2a: Openness to Experience will positively predict universal-diverse orientation, past and potential support for workplace diversity initiatives, and willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H2b: Agreeableness will positively predict universal-diverse orientation, past and potential support for workplace diversity initiatives, as well as willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H2c: The universal-diverse orientation measure will mediate the links between personality traits (Openness to Experience and Agreeableness) and willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions.

H2d: The universal-diverse orientation measure will mediate the links between personality traits (Openness to Experience and Agreeableness) and past and future diversity initiative support.

registration_responses.q1: Impact of Personality on Attitudes towards Diversity and Diversity Initiatives
registration_responses.q3:
In the recent years, there has been an increased interest in examining attitudes towards diversity and diversity initiatives. Some of this work has started to investigate potential factors that motivate people’s endorsement for diversity initiatives. One such factor is trait personality. Trait personality has been consistently shown to play a role in predicting many important life outcomes, e.g., academic and workplace performance, relationship outcomes, health issues, social attitudes, etc. (e.g., Soto, 2019). Thus, it is reasonable to suggest that trait personality also likely predicts people’s attitudes towards diversity.

Within the literature that examined the relationships between attitudes towards diversity and Big Five personality traits, it has been shown that trait Openness to Experience is the most relevant personality variable in predicting receptiveness to diversity, and its relationship to diversity is motivated by an interest to explore and understand differing perspectives. Another relevant trait is Agreeableness, and it is motivated by an interest to care for and empathize with other individuals. Different studies have found significant positive relationships between Openness and Agreeableness with the universal-diverse orientation (UDO), the mostly frequently used diversity measure in the literature (Han & Pistole, 2017; Strauss & Connerley, 2003). The construct of UDO (Miville, 1999) is generally assessed using the M-GUDS Scale, and has been shown to be positively related to positive racial identity (for both Blacks and Whites), empathy, and feminism, as well as negatively related with dogmatism and homophobia. Zhang and Goldberg (2014) found that Openness was positively correlated with pro-diversity belief and sensitivity to diversity, whereas Agreeableness was only related to pro-diversity belief.

Although studies have explored the general relationships between the Big Five traits (notably Agreeableness and Openness to Experience) and varying diversity measures, fewer studies have extended these findings into more practical, real-life settings, e.g., the workplace. The studies that do discuss practical implications for diversity trainings and initiatives in light of personality differences (Han & Pistole, 2017; Zhang & Goldberg, 2014), still do not focus on specific workplace outcomes or diversity initiatives. On the other hand, research that does specifically address receptivity to diversity in the workplace fails to consider individual personality differences as variables that may impact diversity attitudes. Instead, these studies tend to focus on basic demographic variables, such as race and gender, interpersonal relationships, and organizational culture (Soni, 2000).

The current studies aim to fill in these links within the literature by examining both attitudes towards diversity in general and attitudes towards diversity initiatives in the workplace, while focusing on the potential influences of individual differences. Study 1 explored the relationships between Big Five personality and attitudes that employees have toward diversity in the workplace. Study 2 aimed to in part replicate the findings of Study 1, as well as extend Study 1 by investigating how personality and general attitudes towards diversity related to potential diversity initiatives proposed by the individual’s employer, to capture both past and potential future support. We also examined whether personality and attitudes towards diversity would predict participants’ willingness to donate to other diversity-supporting institutions (Studies 1 and 2).
registration_responses.q4:
Study 1 Hypotheses:
H1a: Openness to Experience will positively predict all three diversity measures (universal-diverse orientation, pro-diversity belief, and sensitivity-to-diversity), as well as willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H1b: Agreeableness will positively predict two of the diversity measures, (universal-diverse orientation and pro-diversity belief), as well as willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H1c: The three diversity measures will mediate the links between personality traits (Openness to Experience and Agreeableness) and willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions.

Study 2 Hypotheses:
H2a: Openness to Experience will positively predict universal-diverse orientation, past and potential support for workplace diversity initiatives, and willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H2b: Agreeableness will positively predict universal-diverse orientation, past and potential support for workplace diversity initiatives, as well as willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions, even after controlling for relevant demographic variables, e.g., gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation.

H2c: The universal-diverse orientation measure will mediate the links between personality traits (Openness to Experience and Agreeableness) and willingness to donate to diversity-supporting institutions.

H2d: The universal-diverse orientation measure will mediate the links between personality traits (Openness to Experience and Agreeableness) and past and future diversity initiative support.

q1.value: Adolescent Math Motivation and Social Media Experiences (AMASE)

q3.value: Research on the gender gap in math-related science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields has long identified the stereotype that math is for boys and men, with women who pursue STEM careers often considered unfeminine. A primary component of Western femininity is investment in one’s appearance, and indeed a pervasive appearance-related math stereotype (i.e., that people who pursue math are unconcerned with their physical appearance and often unkempt or unattractive as a result) abounds in popular culture and media. However, no empirical work has examined the effect of this stereotype on adolescent girls’ math engagement.  Moreover, highly visual social media, which emphasizes the value of physical attractiveness, has recently become ubiquitous among American adolescents. The current study will examine how appearance-related math stereotypes affect adolescents’ motivation to succeed in math and if adolescent girls’ investment in their appearance and visual social media exposure further reduces math motivation.

q4.value:
1.	Greater endorsement of appearance-related math stereotypes will be negatively associated with concurrent and later motivation to succeed in math. 
2.	Greater endorsement of appearance-related math stereotypes will be negatively associated with concurrent and later math performance.
3.	Greater endorsement of appearance-related math stereotypes will be positively associated with concurrent and later math anxiety.
4.	Greater endorsement of appearance-related math stereotypes will be negatively associated with concurrent and later enjoyment of math.
5.	Greater endorsement of appearance-related math stereotypes will be negatively associated with concurrent and later math self-concept.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: Our sample will include 8th grade students from large, diverse, suburban middle schools chosen by the CLRN. The final sample size will reflect the maximum number of students who are eligible and available for testing within the allotted time provided by the middle school.

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above.

question.value:
Independent variables:
(1)	Appearance-related math stereotype endorsement: self-reported agreement with stereotypes that people who succeed in math are uninvested in their appearance or unattractive.
(2)	Social media use: frequency of social media use on various platforms, frequency of checking social media during school and while doing homework, frequency of editing one’s photos before posting.
(3)	Investment in appearance: appearance-related social media consciousness (i.e., concern about one’s appearance on social media), appearance-contingent self-worth, value of attractiveness on social media vs. in real life. 
(4)	Attitudes and beliefs about gender: conformity to masculine norms index, attitudes towards women scale, communal and agentic traits.

Dependent variables:
(1)	 Math outcomes: motivation to succeed in math, math performance, math anxiety, enjoyment of math, and math self-concept.

Covariates will include gender, age, race/ethnicity, and a measure of perfectionism. Gender will also be examined as a moderator, as described in the exploratory analyses section. 

We also include a novel photo-rating task as a measure of appearance-related math stereotypes to assess the endorsement of these ideas with reduced social desirability bias. Participants are asked to rate the likelihood that same-aged peers are good at math, art, writing, and science on a 21-point scale ranging from -10 (very unlikely) to 10 (very likely). Images of female peers are manipulated to show high investment in appearance (i.e., wearing makeup) and low investment in appearance (i.e., natural appearance). This variable will act as a predictor in analyses as described in the exploratory analyses section, below.

All variables will be self-reported with the exception of demographic information and academic performance, obtained via school records.

All scale measures will be averaged to create mean composite variable scores. 

The appearance-related math stereotype photo-rating task asks participants to rate images of same-aged peers on likelihood of skill in four academic subjects (math, art, writing, science). Each participant will receive a score for each image as a standardized difference score of the rated skill on humanities subjects (i.e., art and writing) compared to math. Participants’ rated scores for images high in appearance investment will be averaged as will images low in appearance investment.

(1)	To test hypothesis 1, a linear regression model will be used with self-reported appearance-related math stereotypes as the predictor, motivation to succeed in math as the outcome, and gender and race/ethnicity as covariates. The model will be run cross-sectionally (with math motivation at T1 as the dependent variable) and longitudinally (with math motivation at T2 as the dependent variable, controlling for math motivation at T1).
(2)	To test hypothesis 2, a linear regression model will be used with self-reported appearance-related math stereotypes as the predictor, math performance as the outcome, and gender and race/ethnicity as covariates. The model will be run cross-sectionally (with math performance at T1 as the dependent variable) and longitudinally (with math performance at T2 as the dependent variable, controlling for math performance at T1).
(3)	To test hypothesis 3, a linear regression model will be used with self-reported appearance-related math stereotypes as the predictor, math anxiety as the outcome, and gender and race/ethnicity as covariates. The model will be run cross-sectionally (with math anxiety at T1 as the dependent variable) and longitudinally (with math anxiety at T2 as the dependent variable, controlling for math anxiety at T1).
(4)	To test hypothesis 4, a linear regression model will be used with self-reported appearance-related math stereotypes as the predictor, math enjoyment as the outcome, and gender and race/ethnicity as covariates. The model will be run cross-sectionally (with math enjoyment at T1 as the dependent variable) and longitudinally (with math enjoyment at T2 as the dependent variable, controlling for math enjoyment at T1).
(5)	To test hypothesis 5, a linear regression model will be used with self-reported appearance-related math stereotypes as the predictor, math self-concept as the outcome, and gender and race/ethnicity as covariates. The model will be run cross-sectionally (with math self-concept at T1 as the dependent variable) and longitudinally (with math self-concept at T2 as the dependent variable, controlling for math self-concept at T1).


Gender and race/ethnicity are related to sociocultural norms about appearance ideals and the importance of physical attractiveness, as well as stereotypes about social groups that typically succeed in math. Therefore, these demographic variables will be considered as covariates in models investigating stereotypes about appearance and math.

q20.value: We do not anticipate needing transformation of data. If necessary, we will transform skewed data using conventional techniques (e.g., log transformation).

q21.value: We will use conventional two-tailed null hypothesis significance tests with a significance cut-off of p < .05. We will correct for multiple comparisons using Bonferroni-corrected p-values when necessary.

q22.value: We do not expect to exclude outliers unless they indicate errors in data collection.

q23.value: Missing responses will be addressed with either pairwise deletion or maximum likelihood estimation.

q24.value:
Exploratory analyses will be run considering the effect of social media exposure and appearance investment on the association between appearance-related math stereotypes and math outcomes concurrently and longitudinally.

The effect of gender on the association between appearance-related math stereotypes and all math outcomes, concurrently and longitudinally, will also be examined.

Exploratory analyses will also be run using the photo-rating task as a measure of implicit appearance-related stereotype endorsement. Bivariate correlations will be conducted using the photo-rating and self-reported measures of stereotype endorsement to assess their association. Linear regression models will be run as described in the analysis section above with the implicit stereotype endorsement measure, rather than the self-report measure, as a predictor.

Exploratory models including perfectionism as a covariate will also be run, to assess the unique impact of appearance-related math stereotypes on math outcomes controlling for adolescents’ tendency to seek success generally. 

Finally, exploratory regression analyses will be conducted investigating the impact of gender norm adherence on math outcomes, including the interaction between gender norm adherence and appearance-related math stereotypes on later math outcomes.

The model will be run cross-sectionally (with math self-concept at T1 as the dependent variable) and longitudinally (with math self-concept at T2 as the dependent variable, controlling for math self-concept at T1).


Gender and race/ethnicity are related to sociocultural norms about appearance ideals and the importance of physical attractiveness, as well as stereotypes about social groups that typically succeed in math. Therefore, these demographic variables will be considered as covariates in models investigating stereotypes about appearance and math.

attributes.title: Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors and fracture risk in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus: A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

q1.value: Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors and fracture risk in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus: A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

q2.value: Yake Lou, Ying Yu, yake lou, Xiaomin Nie, Yujie Zhou

q4.value: In patients with type 2 diabetes what is the effect of sodium glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors compared with placebo or any other diabetes treatment regimen regarding fracture risk.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Searchh:The following electronic bibliographic databases will be searched: PubMed, EMBASE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) and ClinicalTrials.gov(https://ClinicalTrials.gov/).The search strategy will include only terms relating to or describing the intervention. In addition, we will manually search the reference list of included trials and relevant meta-analyses. No restriction in language.There will be no restriction on year publication. The search strategy will be conducted in duplicate and independently.
 Condition or domain being studied:Fracture risk related to SGLT2i.
Participants/population:Patients with diabetes mellitus treated with sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors.
Intervention(s), exposure(s):Treatment with sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors.
Comparator(s)/control:Standard care based on the criteria of each individual eligible study, placebo, or any other non-SGLT2 inhibitor medication.
 Types of study to be included:Clinical trials, follow up, sub analyses, and post hoc analyses of clinical trials.
Main outcome(s):Any fracture.
Data extraction (selection and coding):Data extraction will be performed by at least 2-3 reviewers. We will extract general baseline characteristics data, outcome data and other relevant data.
Risk of bias (quality) assessment:Two review authors will independently use the Cochrane risk of bias tool to assess the quality of RCTs
based on the following domains: random sequence generation (selection bias), allocation concealment (selection bias), blinding (performance bias and detection bias), incomplete outcome data (attrition bias), selective reporting (reporting bias) and other bias.
Strategy for data synthesis:We will perform a quantitative synthesis of aggregate data from included studies. A quantitative synthesis will be used if the studies are sufficiently homogenous.
Analysis of subgroups or subsets:We will perform subgroup analysis based on SGLT2i type, duration of SGLT2i use, type of control and any other factors that can affect the outcome.
Type and method of review:intervention,meta-analysis,systematic review
Current review status:ongoing

attributes.title: Research protocol for a mixed-methods study to characterise and address the socioeconomic impact of accessing TB diagnosis and care in Nepal
attributes.description: This mixed-methods study in Nepal will: evaluate the socioeconomic impact of accessing TB diagnosis and care (Project 1); and create a shortlist of feasible, locally-appropriate interventions to mitigate this impact (Project 2). The study will be conducted in the Chitwan, Mahottari, Makawanpur, and Dhanusha districts of Nepal.

attributes.title: Arab Support for Building the Bomb: Results from a Survey Experiment on Nuclear Proliferation in the Middle East

q1.value: Arab Support for Building the Bomb: Results from a Survey Experiment on Nuclear Proliferation in the Middle East

q5.value: Funding for the survey was provided through the University of Tennessee's Institute for Nuclear Security

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The dilemma of dual-use technologies is a critical topic in studies of nuclear security. This is especially true in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA), a region that has experienced a “nuclear renaissance” since 2000. Many MENA states have sought to develop or acquire civilian nuclear technology. Yet, risks emerge that such civilian nuclear technology could be diverted to building a nuclear weapon, the so-called “dual-use” problem. Even after a state has signed nonproliferation agreements and pledged to reserve nuclear technology for civilian use, such as energy or desalinization, it is conceivable that it could face national security threats that motivate the weaponization of this technology. Examples from outside the MENA, notably North Korea, indicate that states that have signed nonproliferation treaties can opt out to build a nuclear bomb and pursue aggressive nuclear strategies. Different explanations have sought to predict why states choose to weaponize civilian nuclear technology, previously reserved for peaceful purposes. State-centric research emphasizes incentives created by threats in the international system. If one state converts peaceful nuclear technology into a weapon, then neighboring states undertake a similar strategy for deterrence. The fact that all states fear the possible consequences of nuclear war does not discrouage proliferation but it does foster a “nuclear balance” of peace among states. Other studies look at domestic politics, and how individual leaders might earn political points by weaponizing nuclear technology. Egypt’s Jamal ‘Abdel Nasser and Pakistan’s Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, for example, improved their domestic political positions by re-directing civilian nuclear technology to military programs. Little research, however, has examined the role of citizen attitudes in this process, and public opinion on decisions to weaponize technology in nuclear latent states. The conditions under which citizens express support for the weaponization of nuclear technology previously reserved for peaceful, civilian purposes has been underexplored. How might the identity of an enemy state posing a hostile threat affect citizen attitudes toward weaponization? In the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region, does a hypothetical threat from Iran, Israel, or another Arab state have a larger effect in raising (or depressing) Arab public support for building and, ultimately, using a nuclear bomb? Because Iran, Israel, and neighboring Arab states vary in their military strength, nuclear capacities, and cultural traits, it is likely that citizens of an Arab state receiving the threat—in this study, Morocco—will not perceive these threats equally. Rather, threats issued from one of these states may be more (or less) likely to increase citizens’ support for building and using a nuclear bomb. To investigate this topic, this project proposes to use a population-based survey experiment to explore citizen attitudes toward the dual-use problem of nuclear technology. Specifically, the project will use funding from the University of Tennessee’s Institute for Nuclear Security to conduct a 2000 person survey experiment in Morocco, a nuclear latent state in the MENA region that has an active civilian nuclear program since the 1980s. Building off this survey, the project will seek to assess the generalizability of these results in other MENA states that have also sought or recently obtained nuclear technology.

q16.value: Numerous hypotheses (included in the pre-analysis plan) predict how respondents' support for the building of a nuclear bomb and utilizing aggressive nuclear strategies may vary in response to a hypothetical threat from another Arab state (Jordan), Iran, or Israel. The project seeks to prove whether a hypothetical threat from an Arab state (Jordan), Iran, or Israel provide a stronger impetus of bomb-building and more aggressive nuclear strategies. The hypotheses explaining why one state may be seen as more threatening than another relate to cultural closeness, military strength, policy differences, latent prejudice against Shia and Jewish citizens, ideological opposition to certain political currents, international condemnation, and other theories (all explained in depth in the pre-analysis plan).

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested through a population-based survey experiment in Morocco, a nuclear latent state in the MENA region. The survey experiment will include a vignette treatment that experimentally varies the identity of the country posing the hypothetical threat to Morocco. Then, the survey will ask a variety of dependent variable questions that gauge citizen support for the following nuclear policies on a scale of 4-1 (strongly agree, agree, disagree, strongly disagree). This scale parallels the 4-point likert scale used in the Arab Barometer. The main dependent variable questions ask about respondent support for the following nuclear policies: Building a nuclear bomb; using a nuclear bombs to prevent war; pre-emtively using a nuclear bomb to pre-empt war; engaging in nuclear bluffing; buying immediately a nuclear bomb. A final question also evaluates perceptions of international condemnation following the hypothetical threat.

q27.value: Dr. Matt Buehler in collaboration with Dr. Mhammed Abderrebbi (Moroccan polling company)
